that there's this underlying thread of safety 
being really important and that's something that's

really important to me and i was just wondering 
if you could expand on that a little bit yeah i

think that first i have to say what what i believe 
psychological safety is and to me psychological

safety is not to feel comfortable all the time but 
to be comfortable even in uncomfortable situations

so that you can go into a situation where there's 
some sort of conflict or where there's people who

disagree on things and you have to do something 
for the first time and you can still feel okay

with it to me that's psychological safety and i 
agree that there's a huge overlap with how to do

good retrospectives there are many ways of 
facilitating retrospectives but i am aware that

some ways are better than others which is why 
i wrote the book and the thing about feeling

safe in a retrospective is really important 
because the point with the retrospective is that

as a team you should share and appreciate 
and learn from what has happened and if you

if you don't feel safe you might not want 
to share the things that didn't go very well

because maybe you want to cover up that something 
went wrong you made a mistake or you were afraid

or or said about something somebody said 
and also it's very difficult to appreciate

what happened and will appreciate i mean both 
appreciating in the positive and negative sense

acknowledging that these things happened and it 
actually didn't make us a better team and i think

you're not really able to acknowledging that 
in honest unless you have the safety and then

the last thing about learning i think it's really 
important to to learn to feel safe and that's also

something that i apply a lot when i'm teaching at 
the university is that if the students don't feel

safe to ask questions if they don't feel safe 
to say there's something they don't understand

then it's very difficult to learn that's that's 
really interesting so there's a couple of things

that stuck out there for me that the first one 
around being kind of comfortable almost being

uncomfortable and that's something that i really 
certainly in my own practice when i'm delivering

retrospectives and and anyone anyone that has been 
in a retrospective that i've facilitated i think

in in the last four or five years will testify to

a nice story is a uh i delivered a retrospective
